ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: When we read Fire Drill, we talked about where children and objects were using location words.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Review Vocabulary Let’s review our location words. Use the near Vocabulary Card to reteach the word. Review other key location words that will be helpful for this activity: in front of, behind, above, and under.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In this activity, we will look at cards that show children in many different places. I will ask questions about where the children are and what is around them. Then you will answer using location words.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Ask Show children the first Activity Card. Ask the question listed on the card. Encourage children to answer, repeating the location word used.
Challenge Invite children to use another location word to describe where the child is and what is around him. For example: There is a computer above the boy.
Extend Ask children to describe their own position using the first location word. For example: What is under you right now?
Repeat Continue with the remaining Activity Cards.

Talk About Placement Discuss that many location words are opposites: When we said that the boy was under the table, we could also say the table was above the boy. Invite children to discuss other sets of location words that are opposites, such as behind and in front of. Ask, Was it hard to decide which location word to use? How did you choose?
Model how to describe items using location words: The boy is under the table. Is the boy near the table? Limit the activity to only two or three terms, like near, over, and under.
Invite children to use other location words they may know to describe each picture, such as between, beside, below, and on.

As you review location words, model using a concrete object such as a Connecting Cube. When you show a card, point to important items and review their names, such as computer, table, and flowers, before asking children to describe their location. Use sentence clozes as necessary.

Invite children to act out the location word for each card. Have them put their hands under their legs, above their heads, in front of their faces, or behind their backs. Encourage them to get up and move as well, sitting under a table or standing behind a chair.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: As we read Fire Drill, we saw the children follow instructions and move their bodies carefully for a fire drill. In this activity we are going to see if we can follow instructions and move very carefully.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Review Vocabulary Let’s review the word carefully. Use the carefully Vocabulary Card to reteach the word. Demonstrate by making careful movements and checking surroundings before moving.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In this activity, I will give you an instruction one of two ways. I will either tell you what to do, or tell you what to do carefully. Listen to what I say, and do your best careful or not careful movements!

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Model Demonstrate careful and not careful movements. First say, Put your hands on your head, and plop your hands on your head. Then say, Put your hands on your head CAREFULLY, and model very slowly and gently placing your hands on your head, looking around to make sure you aren’t bumping into anyone or anything.
Repeat Continue with instructions, sometimes repeating actions. Make sure children act carefully when instructed. Encourage them to exaggerate being careful as they practice.

Talk About Being Careful Invite children to discuss the differences between doing an action normally and doing the same action carefully. Point out the importance of being aware of not just your own body, but those around you.
Encourage children to slow down and think about their motions, being thoughtful and deliberate about how they move. If necessary, have children sit on the floor for the first round.
Have a child be the leader giving instructions. Make sure the leader is giving both careful and not careful instructions. Help the leader model the correct motions when necessary.
In addition to the word carefully, review the words for body parts, movements, and location words before starting this activity.
Following the instructions and exaggerating gestures can help children practice gross motor skills. Encourage children to make their movements as large and precise as possible.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you will need an unequal amount of two manipulatives, such as Connecting Cubes and Two-Color Counters. Create a grid on the table using painter’s tape to make equal sized boxes.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: As we read Fire Drill, we kept track of children and adults using Connecting Cubes. We also made a chart of triangles, circles, and squares. Now we are going to make a chart using real objects!
In this activity, we are going to compare two types of items and see which has more by arranging them into a graph and looking at them.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Lay out your tape and the objects you are sorting.
Model Pick up one Connecting Cube. Announce that it is a cube, and put it in a column for cubes. Do the same with one Two-Color Counter.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Can you continue to sort these into cubes or counters? Let’s add them to the graph one at a time.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Repeat Continue with each child taking a turn picking up an item and placing it in the correct column until all items are sorted.
Extend Have children share which there are more of, cubes or counters. Ask how they can tell.
Talk About Graphs Invite children to discuss both the graph they made during the activity and the one made previously. Ask what they think each graph should be called, and what they can see in each.

Start with fewer items with uniform colors, such as five blue Connecting Cubes and two Two-Color Counters, showing the same side. Help children determine which column each item should go in one at a time.
After your tabletop chart is complete, work with children to use technology in the classroom to create a digital, two-column graph.

Begin the activity by using the Number Cards to review counting numbers one to ten. Also, review the names of both item types, making sure the children understand the connection between the word and the activity.

Children may be distracted by classroom noise and have trouble focusing on the activity. Give each child the next item they will place in advance of placing it so they can start thinking about where to place it in advance. Some children may have an easier time sorting all items first and then placing them on the chart.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials For this activity, you will need Connecting Cubes in multiple colors, and a book or folder to use as a “curtain.”

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: In Five Little Froggies Jumping on the Bed, we talked about where the frogs were, and how they did not listen to the doctor at first. For this activity, we are going to practice putting Connecting Cubes in the right places by listening to the person giving instructions.

In this activity, I will arrange two or three Connecting Cubes behind this curtain. I will tell you how my cubes are arranged, but I will not show them to you. You will arrange your cubes the same way on the other side of the curtain. Then, I will lift up the curtain and we will see if our cubes match!

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Place a green Connecting Cube on top of a blue Connecting Cube hidden behind your curtain. Leave extra cubes of all colors on the table for children.

Ask I put a green Connecting Cube on top of a blue Connecting Cube. Can you put a green Connecting Cube on top of a blue Connecting Cube? Have children set up the cubes independently. Then lift the curtain. Compare your arrangements and help correct any misunderstandings.
Repeat Describe cube arrangements using different colors and numbers of cubes. Vary the location words in each round.
Talk About Locations Ask children to explain how they arranged their Connecting Cubes. Discuss which location terms were difficult, then practice making arrangements together using those terms.

To simplify the activity, use the same two colors every time, regardless of which arrangement you set up behind the curtain. This creates less for the children to keep track of as they recreate your arrangements.

Switch roles with the children. Have children come up with their own arrangements for you to copy behind the curtain. If your arrangement doesn’t match the child’s, ask questions to help the child determine what caused the difference.

Begin the activity by reviewing position words such as on, beside, next to, in front of, near, far, and behind with two different colored Connecting Cubes. Use these manipulatives to model placement using location words.

Explain that there is sometimes more than one location word that means the same thing. For example, you could say the blue Connecting Cube is on top of the red Connecting Cube, or that the red Connecting Cube is under the blue Connecting Cube. You could also describe two Connecting Cubes as being near each other or close to each other.
